revision_history.draft:
The car’s skeleton lies smothered in silt,  
its chrome a fossilized sigh—  
plastic ribs dissolved by the current’s pulse,  
while coral tendrils stitch the void.  
A ship’s ribs, once iron, now bleached to bone,  
are etched by tides that remember nothing  
but the slow grind of salt into stone.  
Conveyor belts of silt drag debris  
into the maw of the deep’s slow breath,  
where even steel learns to rust in silence.  
The ocean does not mourn the things it takes—  
it only hums, a low, endless note,  
as layers of time bury the mark  
of hands that tried to name the dark.

The car’s skeleton lies smothered in silt,  
its chrome a fossilized sigh—  
plastic ribs dissolved by the current’s pulse,  
while coral tendrils stitch the void.  
A ship’s ribs, once iron, now bleached to bone,  
are etched by tides that forget all  
but the slow grind of salt into stone.  
Conveyor belts of silt draw debris  
into the maw of the deep’s slow breath,  
where even steel learns to rust in silence.  
The ocean does not mourn the things it takes—  
it only sings, a low, eternal hymn,  
as layers of time erase the mark  
of hands that tried to name the dark.

final_poem:
The car’s skeleton lies smothered in silt,  
its chrome a fossilized sigh—  
plastic ribs dissolved by the current’s whisper,  
while coral tendrils stitch the void.  
A ship’s ribs, once iron, now bleached to bone,  
are etched by tides that forget  
the slow grind of salt into stone.  
Conveyor belts of silt draw debris  
into the maw of the deep’s slow breath,  
where even steel rusts in silence.  
The ocean does not mourn the things it takes—  
it only sings, a low, eternal hymn,  
as layers of time erase the mark  
of hands that sought to name the dark.
